title: 112_hr3482
content: The Internal Revenue Service must act within 90 days of being notified of identity theft to determine the impact on the taxpayer's return and take corrective actions. Disclosure of return information is allowed in federal and state prosecution cases related to identity fraud. The IRS can disclose return information to law enforcement agencies investigating identity theft and fraudulent tax returns upon meeting specific requirements. The IRS can disclose return information to law enforcement agencies investigating crimes related to misuse, but only if part of a team with the Internal Revenue Service. Information disclosed is solely for use in the investigation and must meet specific requirements set by the head of the agency involved. The IRS can disclose return information to law enforcement agencies for investigations, with specific requirements set by the agency head. Amendments to the Code allow for disclosures under certain subsections, effective after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4. Criminal penalty for using a false identity in tax fraud. Section 7207 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include penalties for misappropriating someone's tax identification number, with fines up to $25,000 ($200,000 for corporations) and imprisonment for up to 5 years. The amendments made by this section apply to returns and information submitted after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 5 increases penalties for improper disclosure or use of information by preparers of returns in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendment raises the penalty from $250 to $1,000 and from $10,000 to $50,000. The criminal penalty is also increased from $1,000 to $100,000. These changes apply to disclosures or uses after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 6 introduces a PIN system to prevent identity theft tax fraud. The Secretary of the Treasury must implement an identity theft tax fraud prevention program within a year of this Act. This program allows individuals to receive a unique personal identification number for their tax returns or prevent the processing of electronic tax returns without this number. Additional identity verification safeguards will be provided for tax returns without the unique personal identification number. Individuals can receive a unique personal identification number for their tax returns to prevent processing without it. SEC. 7 allows the Commissioner of Internal Revenue to transfer up to $10,000,000 to the "Enforcement" account for tax fraud enforcement purposes. SEC. 8 establishes the position of Local Law Enforcement Liaison within the Criminal Investigation Division of the IRS to coordinate tax fraud investigations with state and local agencies, communicate on tax fraud cases involving identity theft, and perform other duties as assigned by the Commissioner of Internal Revenue. SEC. 9 requires the Commissioner to submit an annual report on tax fraud to the Senate and House committees, detailing reports received and actions taken. SEC. 10 calls for a study on the use of prepaid debit cards and tax preparation software in tax fraud. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on prepaid debit cards and tax software's role in fraudulent tax returns due to identity theft. A report will be submitted to the Senate and House committees within a year. Additionally, there will be restrictions on access to the Death Master File. The Secretary of Commerce will not disclose information from the Death Master File regarding individuals who have died in the current or following calendar year unless the person requesting access is certified under a fraud prevention program established by the Secretary. Any person certified under the fraud prevention program who discloses or uses information for purposes other than fraud prevention will be penalized $1,000 per violation, not exceeding $50,000 in a calendar year. The Social Security Administration is not required to disclose certain records of deceased individuals to uncertified individuals. The program established under section 9(b) protects information from disclosure to uncertified individuals. This section is considered a statute under section 552 of title 5, United States Code. SEC. 12. EXTENSION OF AUTHORITY TO DISCLOSE CERTAIN RETURN INFORMATION TO PRISON OFFICIALS. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 removes a subparagraph, requires the Federal Bureau of Prisons to submit a plan to Congress on reducing prison tax fraud, and urges State prison authorities to develop plans and coordinate with the IRS to combat tax fraud. SEC. 13. Treasury report on information sharing barriers regarding identity theft. The Secretary of the Treasury will review current tax laws on confidentiality and disclosure of return information to enhance enforcement of identity theft statutes. Consultation with State and local law enforcement will be conducted. A report on the results must be submitted within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary will submit a report with review results and legislative recommendations to the Senate Finance Committee and House Ways and Means Committee. The Attorney General is authorized to award grants to State and local law enforcement agencies for investigating and prosecuting tax crimes. $50,000,000 is authorized to be appropriated annually for this purpose from the Edward Byrne Memorial Justice Assistance Grants program.
